column3: I dont think this is true? sizeof() an array declared immediately previously should be the number of bytes allocated for it, not the size of the pointer (as it would be if you had passed it through a function without size).\n

NACK,  I'd be surprised if this doesn't produce identical ASM.\n`sizeof(pchBuf) == 0x10000` since the `char[dimension]` **array type** is declared in scope, and has not yet degenerated to a pointer.\n
Thank you for the comments! It's an XT-only bug, I was adapting it to core and didn't realise.. Thanks!\n
We should probably just use `std::array` in these situations anyway... maybe\n
@dcousens Need c++11 first. Though in this case with no iteration, movement, or initialization, it wouldn't really buy us anything.\n
@theuni that point when you've been using C++11 so long. I didn't even know that was C++11...\n
